description.value: Small complete scarab, made of beige steatite. Some details carved, brownish glaze, with incised lines.   No details of the back are shown, except two short horizontal lines at the outer edge of the height between prothorax and elytra. The area of the head is quite stylized. Head but no eyes visible, clypeus shows five lobes. The plates are shown.  The side shows only one incised line leaving a broader lower band without any indication of legs.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. One line of hieroglyphs visible, from right to left: j - Pth (inversed) - nb (sideways).

description.value: Complete scarab, made of egyptian blue paste.   The division between head and prothorax is indicated by a line as is the division between prothorax and elytra. The suture is shown by a single line as well. The head is of a trapezoidal shape, no eyes are visible. The clypeus is shown with one notch in the middle and two framing lines. The side of the scarab shows three carved legs on each side, without details, sitting on top of the base plate.  The seal at the base shows an thin oval line framing the base that is rubbed off at one "corner". Inside a lying lion facing to the right, above his back a sun disc. The orientation of the sealing is longitunidal as is the perforation.

description.value: Fragment of a scarab, made of faience, the left half of the scarab is preserved. Fine details carved, whitish colour with incised lines, faint remains of a light green glaze.   The division between elytra and prothorax is not shown. There was some sort of decoration on prothorax, like a curve. No humeral callosities shown. The head is very stylized, no eyes visible, half of the clypeus is broken off, no lobes indicated, but the plate is carved with small parallel lines.   The side shows a each three legs in relief on top of a band for the base. The legs show small lines for the hair as well.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, the motif shows the upper part of a winged scarab, lined by two other signs, maybe nb-baskets. On top of the kheper a short horizontal line. Perforated along its longitudinal side.

description.value: Steatite scarab: engraved on the base with an elaborate heraldic design. In the centre is the goddess Nekhbet in vulture form, 'en face', with widespread wings holding an ankh sign on one side and a nfr (?) on the other. A winged uraeus is on either side of her head. Below is a beetle flanked either side by a 'm??t' sign and a uraeus. Below all, 'nb' in the exergue.

description.value: Very small scarab made of a light purple quartz, the outline is roughly cut in shape. The back is divided by a single line into prothorax and elytra with the suture cut in a single line. The head is shaped in a triangle with the base towards the outside, the clypeus is indicated by two notches. The beetle is divided from the base by a surrounding line, the hind legs are stylized by one line as well. The base is empty.

description.value: Half of a blue frit scarab, broken along the perforation. Quite abstract without much details, two legs preserved cut in relief, the base does not have an oval framing line, it is engraved with a sun disc and a further sign underneath that is not recognizable anymore (boat?).

description.value: Very small scarab made of a light purple quartz, the outline is roughly cut in shape. The back is divided by a single line into prothorax and elytra with the suture cut in a single line. The head is shaped in a triangle with the base towards the outside, the clypeus is indicated by two notches. The beetle is divided from the base by a surrounding line, the hind legs are stylized by one line as well. The base is empty.

description.value: Very small scarab, made of glazed steatite, completely preserved. Remains of a beige glaze preserved.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. No other details shown on the back. The shape of the head is roughly oval, the clypeus is indicated but no details are shown. The side of the scarab shows three legs on top of a base plate, no further details visible.  The seal at the base does not show an oval line framing the base. Very stylized hieroglyphs show an 'Imn-Ra with two vertical stokes underneath and a nb-basket at the other end. The orientation of the seal is transversal while the perforation of the object is longitudinal.

description.value: Quite small, complete scarab, made of steatite. Some details carved, whitish-grey colour with incised lines.  The division between elytra and prothorax is indicated by an incised line, as is the suture. Both humeral callosities are shown by a short vertical line on the right and a skew line on the left.  Head, eyes, clypeus and plates are shown, clypeus with 4 lobes preserved.  The side shows two legs each in relief, no hairs indicated, on top of a base line that is only separated partly from the legs.   The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. Three hieroglyphic signs in a column: Mn-khpr-ra Medium quality. Perforation along its longitudinal side, slightly askew in the lower part.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Scarab, made of glazed steatite, completely preserved. Remains of a beige glaze preserved, the steatite is beige.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The division between prothorax and elytra is indicated by a short vertical groove at each side. The humeral callosities are indicated by a short vertical line at the site, slightly bent inwards.  The shape of the head is oval and bears four thin vertical grooves The clypeus shows four slightly broader grooves, dividing it into five lobes. The side of the scarab shows one circumferential line, separating the scarab from the base plate, no legs are indicated.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. At both ends a longitudinal nb-basket framing the hieroglyphs 'Imn-Ra in the middle. The orientation of the seal is transversal while the perforation of the object is longitudinal.

description.value: Complete scarab, made of faience, no glaze preserved.  The division between elytra and prothorax is indicated by an incised line that is not horizontally but in a zig-zag. The suture is shown by a single line as well. At the lower part of the back another line parallel to the perforation. On the left side one of the humeral callosities is shown by a triangle, not visible on the right side. Head was preserved, clypeus not visible anymore.  The side shows two legs in relief. Underneath the base part.  The seal at the base shows no circumferential line. Standing pharaoh with a crown, facing to the right, both arms parallel to the body, standing in front of an offering stand. Very weathered, description is based on the drawing of the object card. Perforated along its longitudinal side.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Complete scarab, made of faience of beige colour with faint traces of a light green glaze preserved.  The division between head and prothorax is only shown by its difference in shape, no lines at the back, no details shown at all.  The shape of the head is oval, the clypeus only slightly indicated. The side of the scarab shows three fully carved legs on each side, on top of a base plate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base that is not fully preserved. Inside a squatting Seth animal, facing to the right, sitting on top of a mr-sign. Above Seth three horizontal rounded rectangular signs, like nb tAwy?? The orientation of the seal is longitudinal, as is the perforation of the object.

description.value: Complete scarab, made of faience of beige colour with faint traces of a light green glaze preserved.  The division between head and prothorax is only shown by its difference in shape, no lines at the back, no details shown at all.  The shape of the head is oval, the clypeus only slightly indicated. The side of the scarab shows three fully carved legs on each side, on top of a base plate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base that is not fully preserved. Inside a squatting Seth animal, facing to the right, sitting on top of a mr-sign. Above Seth three horizontal rounded rectangular signs, like nb tAwy?? The orientation of the seal is longitudinal, as is the perforation of the object.

description.value: Small complete scarab, made of beige steatite. Some details carved, no glaze preserved? Division between prothorax and elytra as well as suture shown by an incised line. A small line runs partly around the perforation at the lower end of the elytra. The humeral callosities are shown by triangles.  The head is visible, but no eyes. The clypeus is shown but without details, the plates are visible as well  The side shows two legs on each side in relief, on top of a base line.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. On the left a seated mAa.t figure with a feather on the head and long hairs at the neck? In front a wAs underneath of a small oval unidentified sign, t? Underneath mAa.t and wAs a nb-basket.

description.value: Very small scarab, made of faience, completely preserved. Remains of a beige glaze preserved.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line as are the division lines between prothorax and elytra as well as the suture. The humeral callosities are indicated by a small vertical notch. The shape of the head is trapezoidal, no eyes are visible but the clypeus shows 4 notches. The side of the scarab shows two legs on top of a base plate at each side, no further details visible, no circumferential lines.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. An upright wAD.t facing to the right is incised as only sign. The orientation of the seal is longitudinal. The same can be said for the perforation of the object, which is slightly askew though.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Scarab made of faience, parts of base missing, perforation at one end broken through to the base. Remains of a beige glaze preserved.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The same can be said for the division between prothorax and elytra and the suture. The humeral callosities are shown with an incised triangle, the outer parts of the elytra show a second line at the side and bottom.  The head is oval in shape, the clypeus is indicated but no details are visible. The side of the scarab shows a single line separating the scarab from its base plate, no legs are shown.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. Hieroglyphs show 'Imn-Ra nsw nTr.w The orientation of the seal is longitudinal as is the perforation of the object.

description.value: Scarab, made of grey green faience, slightly chipped off at the back and side.   The division between head and prothorax is shown by two lateral short grooves. No further details shown at the back, few cracks of the material. The shape of the head is trapezoidal, no further details shown. The side of the scarab shows two legs on each side, on top of the base plate.  The seal at the base shows traces at the right of an oval line framing the base. At the top a sun disc, left and right of it two not parallel lines (stylized wings?). Underneath two falcons facing to the right, the lines above might be a flagellum as well, at least of the falcon on the left side. Underneath a nb-basket. The orientation of the seal is longitudinal as is the perforation of the object.

description.value: Glazed, white steatite scarab: engraved on the base, the king as bearded human-headed sphinx holds a maat sign. Below him a bound bearded prisoner lies on his belly. Above the sphinx a small cartouche with, probably the prenomen of Thutmose III. Hole pierced through longitudinally. Abraded. Deposit. Re-issue.

description.value: Small complete scarab, made of blue frit.  Almost no decoration on the back, but on the left side one short horizontal line, two on the right side, probably indicating the division between prothorax and elytra. No head and eyes visible but two triangular areas which are probably the plates are visible. On the lower part of the back a nb-shaped hole in the middle with two lines running up to the top. Rubbed off at the highest part of the back, underneath grey coloured frit visible.  The side shows only one incised line separating it into base and upper part, no legs indicated. The lines are not running completely around the object.  The seal at the base does not show a circumferential line. Three hieroglyphic signs visible: In the upper part, left an uraeus, facing to the right, where a sun disc is visible. Underneath maybe the shield of Neith (R24) horizontally. Perforated along its longitudinal side.

Almost no decoration on the back, but on the left side one short horizontal line, two on the right side, probably indicating the division between prothorax and elytra. No head and eyes visible but two triangular areas which are probably the plates are visible. On the lower part of the back a nb-shaped hole in the middle with two lines running up to the top. Rubbed off at the highest part of the back, underneath grey coloured frit visible.  The side shows only one incised line separating it into base and upper part, no legs indicated. The lines are not running completely around the object.  The seal at the base does not show a circumferential line. Three hieroglyphic signs visible: In the upper part, left an uraeus, facing to the right, where a sun disc is visible. Underneath maybe the shield of Neith (R24) horizontally. Perforated along its longitudinal side.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Almost complete scarab, made of steatite. Relatively little details, whitish-beige colour with incised lines, glazed in white.  The division between elytra and prothorax is indicated by three short incised lines of about 1mm of lenghts, while the suture is not visible. At the left elytron in the lower part two further short lines, but not on the right side. Clypeus and eyes visible but no further details shown.   The side only shows one incised line surrounding the object.   The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. In the middle a p above t and H right of it (p-t-H), the p shows three inner horizontal lines. Left and right of it a vertical line and at the outside of it a thin nb-basket on both sides framing the seal. The perforation, which is longitudinal to the object, is partly broken out, destroying part of the seal where the H is placed.

description.value: Scarab made of glazed steatite, most part of the back is chipped of. Whitish-beige colour with incised lines filled with dark turquoise to green glaze.   The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown in a single line. No suture visible anymore but the break might indicate there was one originally.  The head is shown with a single line, both eyes indicated by incised lines. The clypeus is not indicated. The side of the scarab shows all three legs roughly cut on top of a base plate.  The seal at the base shows a roughly cut oval line framing the base, inside on the left a seated deity with a possible mAa.t-feather on the head, facing to the right. In front of mAa.t a crude ankh-sing? The longitudinal perforation is fully preserved.

description.value: Scarab made of a white pebble with incised lines filled with glazed dark brown to black material. This is a very unusual piece, very thin with both sides showing the back of the scarab, no base with seal is preserved, no sides are indicated either. The area of the head is very unusual as well.  The division between head and prothorax is not clearly shown. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown by a single line with the humeral callosities shown with a wavy line. The suture is shown by a single line as well, getting divided into a triangle at its lower end.  The head is not indicated directly but indirectly by leaving a gap between two very large and round eyes, outside of them a short bent line is found from one end to the other, being glazed only at the outer ends and in a short central part. The clypeus as well as the plates are not shown at all.

description.value: Complete scarab, made of steatite. Fine details carved, whitish-beige colour with incised lines. The surface of the scarab shows small cracks and might therefore be glazed in white.  The division between elytra and prothorax is indicated by an incised line, as is the suture. The suture line stops 0.2 cm above the perforation, showing two perpendicular short lines. Both humeral callosities are shown by triangles.  Head and clypeus and plates are shown, clypeus with 4 lobes preserved, the left plate is partly broken off. The eyes are not visible.    The side shows three legs in relief on each side on top of a base line.   The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. Three figures visible standing on two lines. In the middle Amun with the double feather crown, facing right, behind him on the left maybe a falcon headed deity facing right, with a sun disc above the head (not directly on top of the head), to the right of Amun facing left another figure, probably also falcon-head… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Complete scarab, made of beige steatite. Faint traces of a light green glazing preserved.  The head is divided from the prothorax by a single line. The prothorax is divided from the elytra in one downwards bended line. The humeral callosities are indicated by hollowed out triangles. The suture is shown in a single line and one line surrounds the elytra and the prothorax. The head is stylized by a long thin band with the width of the whole scarab, no eyes visible. The clypeus is divided from the head by a single line, three small notches divide it in four lobes. The side shows two circumferential parallel lines indicating the legs on top of the base plate.  The seal at the base is surrounded by an oval line framing the base. At both longitudinal ends a nb-basket, in the middle a column of mn on top of a horizontal sign, probably n over two t. Perforated along its longitudinal side.

description.value: Sard scarab engraved on the base with a seated ibid-head figure, probably Thoth, and Egyptian hieroglyphic signs in the field; perforated for suspension; the figure faces left, above his head is a disc and crescent, and above this a winged solar disc; on either side are feather-like motifs, the one in front is possibly the ntr sign, the one behind is uncertain; below the figure in the exergue is a crescent-shaped motif; the border is defined by a groove.

description.value: Fragment of a scarab, made of steatite, about a quarter of the scarab is preserved. Fine details carved, whitish-beige colour with incised lines filled with dark green glaze.   The division between elytra and prothorax is indicated by an incised line, as is the suture. One of the humeral callosities is preserved on the right elytron, showing an incised triangle. Also at the side of prothorax and elytron a line indicating the end of the wing cover. Head and clypeus with 2 lobes preserved (originally probably 4),   The side shows two circumferential line defining an area of stylised legs and a base part.  The seal at the base shows faint traces of an oval line framing the base very close to the edge. Parts of three hieroglyphic signs preserved, probably a nb-basket at the base of the seal, on top maybe the lower part of an uraeus.  Medium quality. Part of the longitudinal perforation is preserved.

description.value: Very small scarab made of glazed steatite, most part of the back is missing, parts of the base is chipped of at one side. The steatite is of a grey colour, the glaze is white to light green with the hieroglyphs and area between the legs in a dark green colour.  Concerning the small scale of the scarab, the carving is of a high quality.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The head is oval. The clypeus is clearly divided from the head by a line, no details shown though. The plates at each side are shown in a sunken area next to the head. The side of the scarab shows all three legs carved, the scarab is sitting on top of the base plate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside three hieroglyphs facing to the right: un upright uraeus or wAD.t (I12), behind this a seated mAa.t goddess with the feather, both on top of a nb-basket. The longitudinal perforation is fully preserved.

description.value: Scarab, made of turquoise frit (?), completely preserved.   The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The division between prothorax and elytra is indicated by a single line as well, as is the suture. The latter is not quite in the middle of the back. The humeral callosities are indicated by triangles incised.  The shape of the head is slightly trapezoidal, only two lateral grooves that might indicate the eyes are visible, no clypeus distinguishable.  The side of the scarab shows two legs on each side, on top of a base plate.  The seal at the base shows a very thin oval line framing the base that is only preserved on the right side. From top to bottom a sun disc, underneath a mn-sign with a very thin base line, underneath a kheper with wings, underneath a horizontal line. The execution and shape of the signs seems strange as does the unusual colour of the object. The orientation of the seal is longitudinal as is the perforation of the object.

description.value: Scarab made of steatite, almost completely preserved, only a small part at the base is chipped off. The steatite is of a grey colour, few remains of a whitish glaze visible.  The division between head and prothorax is shown by a single line. The division between prothorax and elytra as well as the suture is shown in a double line. Both prothorax and elytra show a lateral framing line on each side. The humeral callosities are shown by incised triangles, only faintly visible anymore. The head is oval in shape, the eyes are shown. The clypeus is broken off, the plates are visible. The side shows three fully carved legs on each side, sitting on a base plate, no further details shown.  The seal at the base shows a thin oval line framing the base. Inside a squatting cat facing to the right, over its back a fish, also facing to the right. In front of the cat a wDA.t-eye with a brow, above it a sun disc. The motif is oriented transversal, while the perforation is longitudinal.

description.value: Scarab, made of glazed steatite, the back as well as the base is partly chipped of. The steatite is of a grey colour, a beige glaze is preserved everywhere, the hieroglyphs in the base show a faint green colour.  The division between head and prothorax is indicated by a line. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown in a line that consists of two upwards bended parts. The suture is shown by a line as well.  The head is of a trapezoidal shape, no eyes are visible. The clypeus is not preserved, the plates are visible, the one on the left side is divided in two subparts by a line, while the one on the right side is not.  The side of the scarab shows two lateral lines on each side to separate the scarab from the baseplate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, with three recognizable signs in it. On the right an ankh-sign, on the left a sign that was described as a nfr-sign by the EES object card but there are further lines that look like a raised arm? The division between prothorax and elytra is shown in a line that consists of two upwards bended parts. The suture is shown by a line as well.  The head is of a trapezoidal shape, no eyes are visible. The clypeus is not preserved, the plates are visible, the one on the left side is divided in two subparts by a line, while the one on the right side is not.  The side of the scarab shows two lateral lines on each side to separate the scarab from the baseplate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, with three recognizable signs in it. On the right an ankh-sign, on the left a sign that was described as a nfr-sign by the EES object card but there are further lines that look like a raised arm? The si… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Very fine scarab, made of glazed steatite, parts on back and site chipped of. Fine details carved, whitish-beige colour with incised lines filled with dark turquoise to green glaze.   The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The prothorax and elytra itself show a decoration. In the upper part two parallel horizontal bands filled with small squares can be seen, the lower of them probably represents the division between prothorax and elytra. Underneath them on the elytra a lotus flower, no suture visible.  The head is shown with two surrounding lines, both eyes indicated by very small incised lines, not glazed though. The clypeus is indicated by a simple line at each side as well. The side of the scarab shows two circumferential lines leaving a band as stylised legs.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside three erected cobras facing to the right, the two right ones show a more detailed carved shield. The cobra on the left looks like … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Scarab made of glazed steatite, small part at the base is chipped of. The glaze shows a whitish-beige colour.   The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single thin line. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown by a small indent at the sides. No suture visible, two cracks on the back though.  The head is shown with a single line, both eyes indicated by small raised areas. The clypeus is clearly indicated, one thick groove close to the eyes, five small lines at the other end. The plates at each side are clearly visible as well, each subdivided by a small groove into two parts. The side of the scarab shows all three legs with hairs indicated by small grooves, the scarab is sitting on top of a base plate.  The seal at the base shows a cartouche in the middle with (Mn-kheper-Ra)|, left and right of it an uraeus facing the cartouche. The longitudinal perforation is fully preserved.

description.value: Small scarab, chipped off at several parts, upper third of the seal is not preserved, made of grey steatite, no glaze preserved, but the outer side is of a lighter beige colour from the baking.  The division between elytra and prothorax is indicated by an incised line, as is the suture. One elytron shows a bigger hole in it, the other one a smaller hole as well. Both humeral callosities are shown by a triangle. Head and eyes are visible, parts of the clypeus and both plates are broken off.  The side shows three legs each in relief, no hairs indicated, on top of a base line that is only separated partly from the legs.   The seal at the base is broken off in its upper third, it shows a circumferential line. An ibis-bird, with its feet as base line, the head is not preserved, facing to the right side. It stands in front of a cartouche, not legible anymore, but a seated deity in the uppermost preserved part. Perforated along its longitudinal side.

description.value: Scarab made of steatite, remains of a whitish-beige glaze preserved, the steatite is of a beige colour.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a very faint single line, only preserved on the right. The division between prothorax and elytra and the suture is shown in a single line as well. The humeral callosities are marked with an askew line underneath the division line of prothorax and elytra, so that it forms a triangle with the outer for of the body. The head is oval in shape, the clypeus is almost not visible anymore. The side of the scarab shows three fully carved legs on each side, sitting on a base plate, no details are carved, no lines.  The seal at the base shows a thin oval line framing the base. In the middle a Dd-pillar, left and right of it each an uraeus facing to the pillar. The orientation of the seal is longitudinal as is the perforation of the object.

description.value: Complete scarab, made of glazed steatite. The steatite is of a beige colour, few remains of a whitish glaze is preserved.  The division between head and prothorax is indicated by a line as is the division between prothorax and elytra. The suture is shown by a single line as well, the humeral callosities are indicated by incised triangles.  The head is of an oval shape, no eyes are visible. The clypeus is shown without details, framed by two outer lines. The side of the scarab shows three carved legs on each side, without details, sitting on top of the baseplate.  The seal at the base shows an thin oval line framing the base, with several hieroglyphs. On the left a squatting sphinx with wings, beard and uraeus, over the head a sun disc with two uraei. In front ofit a cartouche of Mn-kheper-R', and the hieroglyphs of 'Imn-R' around it. The orientation of the sealing is transversal while the perforation is longitudinal.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Scarab made of green faience, completely preserved, only part of the base chipped of. The head is separated from the prothorax by a simple line. Prothorax and elytra are indicated only by a small indent of the body form, also no suture visible. The clypeus is indicated by two incised lines, eyes not clearly visible but indicated by two slightly deeper impressions in the incised lines.   The side shows two legs at each side on top of a base plate. In the front something that could be either the third leg or a part of the clypeus.  The seal at the base does not show an oval framing line, but is incised with three columns of small hieroglyphs: in the left and right column each a mAa.t-feather over the full height, in the middle a sun-disc above a Dw, underneath a horizontal line (maybe n) above another sun-disc, this could be a corrupt writing of 'Imn-Ra. The perforation along its longitudinal side is fully preserved.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Complete scarab, made of steatite. At the highest part of the back the glaze is rubbed offed. Some details carved, whitish-grey colour with incised lines.   No details of the back with elytra and prothorax are shown, except for a two 0.5 cm long lines at the site edge of the back. The area of the head is quite stylized, head and eyes are not shown but there is a small curved part between two lines.  The clypeus is indicated with five lobes, and outside of the clypeus a small area is shown that could be either plates or part of legs, with hair indicated on the right.  The side shows two lines leaving a line for the legs that are no further carved in details above the base line.   The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. In the centre  a mn-sign. To the right of it a second sign that is joined to it in the base that could have been a sun disc or maybe an uraeus?. Around this two signs nine circles with a hole in the middle.  Perforated along its longitudinal side.

description.value: Almost complete scarab, chipped slightly at the base, clypeus is missing made of steatite. Whitish-beige colour with incised lines, glazed in white.  The division between elytra and prothorax is indicated by an incised line, as is the suture. The outer lines of the elytra as well as the prothorax are shown with two lines. At the back another line parallel to the perforation. The humeral callosities are shown by triangles. Head and eyes preserved, clypeus broken off.  The side shows the legs in fine relief with hairs indicated by small diagonal, parallel lines. Underneath the base part. The back of the scarab is not perfectly symmetrical, one side (the right of the beetle) is higher than the other and therefore it looks a bit irregular.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base very close to the edge. Two columns of hieroglyphs facing right: 1) first sign not preserved, underneath maybe nb - wDA - 'Imn - R'/t-t and maybe a book roll at the edge but this sign joined with … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Almost complete scarab, chipped slightly at the base, clypeus is missing made of steatite. Whitish-beige colour with incised lines, glazed in white.  The division between elytra and prothorax is indicated by an incised line, as is the suture. The outer lines of the elytra as well as the prothorax are shown with two lines. At the back another line parallel to the perforation. The humeral callosities are shown by triangles. Head and eyes preserved, clypeus broken off.  The side shows the legs in fine relief with hairs indicated by small diagonal, parallel lines. Underneath the base part. The back of the scarab is not perfectly symmetrical, one side (the right of the beetle) is higher than the other and therefore it looks a bit irregular.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base very close to the edge. Two columns of hieroglyphs facing right: 1) first sign not preserved, underneath maybe nb - wDA - 'Imn - R'/t-t and maybe a book roll at the edge but this sign joined with … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Scarab, made of glazed steatite, the back is partly damaged. The steatite is of a light grey colour, quite worn and smoothed at the back, remains of beige glaze preserved on the base.  The division between head and prothorax is indicated by a notch at each side. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown in a single line. The suture is not shown.  The head is barely preserved but seemed to have been very stylized without details, the clypeus is shown in two outer lines. The side of the scarab shows one circumferential line for the fore- and hind legs, and one askew line for the middle legs. Underneath one line on each lateral side to separate the scarab from the baseplate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside a thoroughly cutting of an upright wAD.t facing to the right, in front of her a lotus and a flower, underneath a nfr-sign. Both flowers and the nfr-sign are connected by a line to the base of the snake. The longitudinal perforation is fully pre… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Scarab, made of beige steatite, parts on the back and on the sides by the legs chipped off. Light green glazing on all sides, darker green to turquoise in the incised hieroglyphs at the base. The surface shows small cracks on all sides. Division between head and prothorax shown by a curved line. The division between prothorax and elytra is not shown, same is true for the suture.  The head is in the shape of a square turned on edge, no eyes visible. The clypeus with four lobes is shown slightly raised above the plates. The side shows two legs on each side, carved through two horizontal lines and a short vertical one, separating the scarab from its base plate.  The seal at the base shows a circumferential line that is partly lost. On the left side a standing deity facing to the right, maybe Sekhmet with an uraeus at the head (?), holding a staff, standing on top of a nb-basket. Above her head a sun-disc, in front of her an unclear sign like jwn-pillar on a base line, underneath a small n… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Very small scarab made of steatite, only small parts of base is chipped of, the drawing on the object card shows that it was complete when drawn. Few remains of a white glaze preserved at the highest part of the back as well as parts of the base, underneath the grey colour of the steatite is visible.   The division between head and prothorax is shown by a single line. Elytra and prothorax are divided by a single line as well, as is the suture. The humeral callosities are indicated by carved triangles.  The shape of the head is oval, the eyes are very large, the left eye is not completely preserved. The clypeus is broken off. The side shows three fully carved legs, no details shown, sitting on top of the base plate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside are two upright uraei facing to the right, in front of them an unidentified almost rectangular vertical sign, all three above a nb-basket. Above the two snakes each a small nb-basket, the left one is half brok… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Fragment of a scarab, made of steatite, the left third of the scarab is preserved. Fine details carved, whitish-beige colour with incised lines filled with dark turquoise glaze.   The division between elytra and prothorax is only indicated by a 1.6 mm long line. There was some sort of decoration on prothorax and also on elytra but most of it is broken off. The decoration on the elytra looks like a line of small parallel carved lines.  Parts of the head visible, the left eye is preserved and well defined, clypeus is broken off. The side shows a circumferential line as stylised legs, with small vertical parallels lines to indicate the hair of the legs, this was carved in the area of the head and back.   The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, in the middle something like a sunken rectangular field with rounded edges can be seen, the rest is broken off. To the outside of this field it a branchlike decoration. High quality. A small part of the longitudinal perforation is … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Scarab, made of glazed steatite, the base is partly chipped of. The steatite is of a beige colour, a dark green to turquoise glaze is preserved incised parts of the legs, the frontal part and in the hieroglyphs on the base.  The division between head and prothorax is indicated by a line as is the division between prothorax and elytra. The suture is shown by a single line as well, the humeral callosities are indicated by incised triangles and the elytra show a second line on the outside.  The head is of a square shape put on edge, no eyes are visible. The clypeus is shown without details, running into lateral lobes, the plates are not visible.  The side of the scarab shows three carved legs on each side, without details, sitting on top of the baseplate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, with several hieroglyphs centred around the very small cartouche of Thutmosis III. (Mn-kheper-Ra)|. description.value: Scarab made of glazed steatite, small parts of the base are chipped of on two sides. Whitish-beige glazing.   The division between head and prothorax is clearly shown with a single line and relief. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown in a single line, the humeral callosities are shown with triangles.  both elytra are surrounded by a separate line at the side and lower part, the suture is visible through a line as well.  The head is shown with an oval part in relief, both eyes clearly indicated by round areas next to the clypeus. The clypeus itself is partly broken off but seemed to wear three wider grooves. No plates or lobes shown. The side of the scarab shows all three legs cut in fine and detailed relief with the hair indicated by parallel fine lines. Underneath the base plate is visible.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside on the right a small seated mAa.t-figure wearing the feather, facing to the right, on top of a nb-basket, above her … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Complete scarab, made of steatite. Fine details carved, light-grey colour with whitish-beige glaze.   The division between elytra and prothorax is indicated by an incised line, as is the suture. The outer lines of the elytra as well as the prothorax are shown with two lines. The humeral callosities are shown by triangles.  Head, eyes and clypeus with 4 lobes preserved (originally probably 5 lobes).  The side shows the legs in fine relief with hairs indicated by small diagonal, parallel lines. Underneath the base part. The back of the scarab is not perfectly symmetrical, one side (the right of the beetle) is higher than the other and therefore it looks a bit irregular.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base very close to the edge. In the middle a seated deity with beard and wAs-sceptre is shown, maybe Ptah, facing to the right a cartouche with very small sign, maybe (wsr-mAa.t-Ra-...-Ra?)|. Behind the deity on the left a falcon bird with legs(?) and protective wings i… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Scarab, made of glazed steatite (?), the base is partly worn. The scarab is of a beige colour, few traces of a possible white glazing preserved.  The division between head and prothorax is slightly indicated by two short horizontal lines at the sites. Prothorax and elytra are divided by a single line that is bent downwards. The suture is shown by a single line as well. The area between the lower end of the elytra and the hind legs is carved out which seems rather unusual among the material present. The head is of an almost oval shape, no eyes are visible. A faint line separates the clypeus, which is shown without details.  The side of the scarab shows three roughly carved legs on each side defined by three carved lines, the legs are without further details, the scarab is sitting on top of the baseplate.  The seal at the base shows parts of an oval line framing the base, but it is not circumferential which is very unusual as well. Also the motif is weird, showing two nb-baskets on each … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Complete scarab, made of blue frit. Half of the upper part is missing.   Almost no decoration on the back, but on the right side two short horizontal lines, probably indicating the division between prothorax and elytra.  Head and eyes not preserved but one plate in a triangular shape with small askew lines is visible.   The side shows only one incised line separating it into base and upper part, no legs indicated. The lines are not running completely around the object.  The seal at the base shows faint traces of a circumferential line. Standing figure with a falcon head, facing to the right. The right arm is shown along the body, the left arm is winged and raised up, the inner part shows small parallel lines, on the outside the tips of three feathers indicated. Also the inner part of the apron shows horizontal lines. In front of the figure a sign that looks like the lower part of a wAs-sceptre, joining the wing in the upper part. In front of this a small oval another sign, maybe sA or … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Complete scarab, made of blue frit. Half of the upper part is missing.   Almost no decoration on the back, but on the right side two short horizontal lines, probably indicating the division between prothorax and elytra.  Head and eyes not preserved but one plate in a triangular shape with small askew lines is visible.   The side shows only one incised line separating it into base and upper part, no legs indicated. The lines are not running completely around the object.  The seal at the base shows faint traces of a circumferential line. Standing figure with a falcon head, facing to the right. The right arm is shown along the body, the left arm is winged and raised up, the inner part shows small parallel lines, on the outside the tips of three feathers indicated. Also the inner part of the apron shows horizontal lines. In front of the figure a sign that looks like the lower part of a wAs-sceptre, joining the wing in the upper part. In front of this a small oval another sign, maybe sA or … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Scarab made of faience completely preserved. Remains of a light green glaze visible.  The division between head and prothorax is shown by a single line. No further details shown on the back except for two short lines, bent inwards along the side, probably to show the division between prothorax and elytra. The head is oval in shape, the eyes are indicated faintly, one notch in the middle of the head. The clypeus shows three notches dividing it into four lobes, the plates are visible as well.  The side shows three fully carved legs on each side, sitting on a base plate. The frontal leg shows small grooves indicating the hair.  The seal at the base shows a thin oval line framing the base, on the left over the full height a standing Anubis figure in striding pose, facing right, holding a staff. In front of it to the right a mAa.t-feather, above it two horizontally curved lines. Underneath figure and feather a mr-sign as standing line. The motif is very similar to 687, with Thot and 700 wit… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Complete scarab, made of glazed steatite of beige colour with remains of a light green glaze preserved. Many circumferential cracks at the back.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown in a single line as well, as is the suture. No further details visible. The shape of the head is oval, no eyes indicated. The frontal part of the clypeus is broken off, but originally probably showed three grooves, dividing it into four lobes. The plates at the sides are shown as well.  The side of the scarab shows three deep and finely carved legs on each side, no details indicated.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside on the left a standing Thoht-figure over the full height, holding a wAs-sceptre, with crescent and sun disc. In front of the figure a mAa.t-feather, above it a sun disc and above that two short horizontal lines. The motif is very similar to 680 with Anubis and 700 with Re-Harakhte… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Relatively small complete scarab, made of glazed steatite. Beige steatite and remains of a light blue glaze.   The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. Prothorax and elytra are divided with a single line as well, as is the suture. The humeral callosities are shown with an incised triangle. Prothorax and elytra show both an outer second framing line at the side and bottom part on both sides. The head has an trapezoidal shape. The clypeus is shown with three notches dividing it into four lobes, the plates are visible as well. The side shows one circumferential line that divides the scarab and its base plate. The line is bending upwards at the sides towards the middle of the body of the scarab.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. On the right a lying sphinx with wings and beard, facing to the right, with an enigmatic headdress (can this be the joint of a mn-sign with the head?). In front of the sphinx an ankh-sign. The orientation of the … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Complete scarab, made of light grey steatite. At the highest part of the back the glaze and part of the stone is chipped offed. Some details carved, whitish-grey glaze, with incised lines.   No details of the back with elytra and prothorax are shown, except framing lines at the outer edge of the prothorax and at the upper part of the elytra. The area of the head is quite stylized and difficult to see as it is partly destroyed as well. One eye on the left and clypeus is visible, but no partition of the lobes is preserved. The plates are shown with small diagonal lines.  The side shows two incised lines leaving a circumferential band for the legs, in the middle at the side of this band four vertical lines. From this point another line is running to indicate the hind leg by running askew downwards. Underneath is the base line.   The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. Two figures facing each other. On the left Ptah mummy-shaped, with the wAs-sceptre in his both hands. Fr… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Very small scarab, completely preserved, made of glazed steatite. No remains of a glaze preserved.  No division between head and prothorax. The prothorax is divided by short horizontal grooves above and below, the humeral callosities are shown by a vertical short line, leaving from the lower division line of the prothorax. At the lower part of the back a small incised line following the perforation hole. The shape of the head is triangular, the eyes are roughly indicated, the clypeus is shown by a second triangular upside down, but the lower point sits asymmetrical to the right of the head.  The side of the scarab shows one circumferential line, dividing the scarab from the base plate, no legs are indicated.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. Very stylized hieroglyphs show two vertical lines at each end, leaving a nb-basket at the ends which are filled with vertical lines. The prothorax is divided by short horizontal grooves above and below, the humeral callosities are shown by a vertical short line, leaving from the lower division line of the prothorax. At the lower part of the back a small incised line following the perforation hole. The shape of the head is triangular, the eyes are roughly indicated, the clypeus is shown by a second triangular upside down, but the lower point sits asymmetrical to the right of the head.  The side of the scarab shows one circumferential line, dividing the scarab from the base plate, no legs are indicated.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. Very stylized hieroglyphs show two vertical lines at each end, leaving a nb-basket at the ends which are filled with vertical lines. In the middle field a quite rough mn-sign above a horizontal line (n), underneath a sun di… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Scarab made of steatite, only small parts of base and legs chipped of. The greyish glaze is only preserved at the highest part of the back as well as parts of the base, underneath the beige colour of the steatite is visible.   The division between head and prothorax is shown by a line that is not fully consistent. Elytra and prothorax are divided by a small notch at the outer ends, no line though. The same is true for the suture, no humeral callosities as well. The head is very stylized in an almost triangular shape, eyes might be indicated by a small groove, the clypeus is broken off, small lobes indicated by an outline as well.  The side shows two horizontal lines, the upper one is not consistent in the middle part where the legs are attached to the body. Here a third groove is incised vertically on one side, slightly askew on the other side. The second line is consistent and separates the scarab from its base plate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, the oute… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Very fine scarab, made of glazed steatite, completely preserved. Fine details carved, whitish-beige colour with incised lines, remains of beige glaze preserved on the back and base. The cutting of the legs and hieroglyphs at the base are very deep and were not cleaned entirely.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown in a single line, the prothorax itself shows an outer line on the left and right side, the part at the right side is slightly chipped though.  The suture is shown in a single line as well, the elytra each show an outer lining as well. The humeral callosities are indicated by carved triangles.  The head and eyes are raised and glazed, the clypeus with four lobes and the plates are not raised and unglazed. The side of the scarab shows three deep and finely carved legs on each side that show details of hairs in small grooves on all legs. The legs are slightly protruding over the body when seen fr… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Fine and relatively large scarab but very flat, made of glazed steatite, part of one leg is chipped of. Beige steatite and remains of a whitish glaze.   The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. Prothorax and elytra are divided with a double line, from the lower line the humeral callosities are shown with a filled triangle. The suture is shown in a double line as well.  The head has an oval shape, both eyes indicated by very small circles. The clypeus is shown with a short row of four lobes, divided by three notches, and then a second row further down with again four lobes and three notches is shown. The plates are visible as well. The side shows three fully carved legs on each side, above a base plate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside a cartouche of Mn-kheper-R' with two feathers above and two uraei at each side, facing outwards. Above the head of each uraeus a small round sign that could be a stylised crown. Underneath all a… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Very fine scarab, completely preserved, made of glazed steatite. Fine details carved, the steatite is of a beige colour with incised lines filled with dark turquoise glaze.   The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line that bends into the prothorax. The prothorax and elytra are not further separated, gut two vertical bent lines indicate the division. In the upper part of the prothorax, in the middle of the body, a small curved area that might have been an original cut but is slightly broken out now. The head is trapezoidal in shape, both eyes are separated by a line, showing a thin long shape. The clypeus bears two notches at its upper end and four at the lower end. The plates are visible and each bear a notch in the middle.  The side of the scarab shows three clearly cut legs on each side, all showing small grooves indicating the hair, sitting on top of the base plate.  The seal at the base shows three oval lines framing the base, between the first two lines a … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Fine scarab, made of glazed steatite, completely preserved. Remains of white glaze preserved on parts of the back and plate, the steatite is beige.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown in a very thin line as is the suture. The humeral callosities are indicated by a small carved triangle, the outer part of the elytra is lined with a double line at the side and a single line at the bottom. On the right elytrum a mAa.t-feather is incised. The shape of the head is oval, with small round eyes at each side. The clypeus shows remains of three grooves, dividing it into four lobes, but the frontal part is chipped off. The plates at the sides are shown as well.  The side of the scarab shows three finely carved legs on each side that show details of hairs in small grooves on all legs. Seen from the side, the legs are sitting on a base plate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside several… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Scarab, made of glazed steatite, very small part at one end of the perforation is slightly chipped of. The steatite is of a grey colour, a white glaze is preserved on all parts.  The division between head and prothorax is not indicated, the division between prothorax and elytra is shown by two lateral small notches, the area underneath the head shows a sign of a roughly carved circle. No suture is shown. The head and clypeus are shown in one elongated and raised shape, no eyes are visible. The clypeus is shown without details. The area next to the head shows several incised lines that follow the curve of the body. When the object is turned upside down it looks like an abstract human face. The side of the scarab shows one lateral incised line on each side.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside a decorative pattern of four loops arranged in a cross with four triangular shapes in between them, lined with the centre of the loops. description.value: Almost complete scarab, made of steatite, slightly chipped on the back and side of the base. Whitish-beige colour with incised lines, glazed in white.  The division between elytra and prothorax is indicated by two short notches of about 1mm of lenghts, while the suture is not visible. Head and eyes are visible, clypeus is quite large and very detailed, showing two rows of vertical lines indicating the lobes. The lower one shows five lobes and the upper one three. The plates are shown in detail in contrary to other scarabs.   The side shows all legs carved in relief, with small lines indicating the hairs.   The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base. Three standing deities on top of a mr-sign. Above them a sun disc with two uraei, one in each direction. To the right Amun with the double feathered crown, facing to the left, holding hands with the pharaoh in the middle, wearing probably the blue crown, facing right. Behind pharaoh on the left, also holding hands with him, a … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Very fine scarab, made of glazed steatite, completely preserved. Fine details carved, whitish-beige colour with incised lines, remains of beige glaze preserved on the back.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown with notches at the sides as well as a double line, one line running on each side of the notches.  The suture is shown in a double line as well, the humeral callosities are not shown.  The shape of the head is oval, no eyes indicated. The clypeus shows three grooves, dividing it into four lobes. The plates at the sides are shown as well.  The side of the scarab shows three deep and finely carved legs on each side that show details of hairs in small grooves on all legs. The legs are slightly protruding over the body when seen from above. Seen from the side, the legs are sitting on a base plate.  The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside several hieroglyphs. From top to bottom… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Scarab made of glazed steatite. Whitish-beige steatite and remains of a light blue glaze, in few incised parts still dark blue glaze visible. Most parts of the back as well as the seal are chipped off.  The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. Prothorax and elytra are divided with a single line as well that seems to be bending down towards the middle. Also a single line for the suture. The humeral callosities are shown with incised triangles. Prothorax and elytra show both an outer second framing line at the side and bottom part on both sides. The head has an oval shape with a horizontal line in the middle as well as two vertical lines dividing the eyes. The clypeus is shown with three notches at the upper end and four notches at the lower end, the plates are visible as well. The side shows two parallel but not circumferential lines, between them in the middle three vertical notches. Before and behind these notches small grooves at the upper part of the legs… (See Merlin record for full description)
